<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_close:
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_close(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				struct linux_device *ldev)
{
	(void)lbus;
	unsigned int i;

	for (i = 0; i < ldev->device.num_regions; i++) {
		metal_unmap(ldev->device.regions[i].virt,
			    ldev->device.regions[i].size);
	}
	if (ldev->override) {
		sysfs_write_attribute(ldev->override, "", 1);
		ldev->override = NULL;
	}
	if (ldev->sdev) {
		sysfs_close_device(ldev->sdev);
		ldev->sdev = NULL;
	}
	if (ldev->fd >= 0) {
		close(ldev->fd);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No controlling expressions in this function are syntactically invariant constants or obviously constant at compile time. Specifically:
- for (i = 0; i < ldev->device.num_regions; i++) — the loop condition depends on ldev->device.num_regions, which is a runtime value and not a compile-time constant; it is not an invariant controlling expression.
- if (ldev->override) — the condition depends on the runtime value of the pointer ldev->override and is not invariant.
- if (ldev->sdev) — likewise depends on a runtime pointer value and is not invariant.
- if (ldev->fd >= 0) — this depends on the runtime file-descriptor value and is not an invariant compile-time constant.
- There are no do-while loops with a constant false controlling expression, nor any explicit infinite-loop constructs that would rely on an invariant controlling expression (the permitted exception for intentional infinite loops does not apply here).

Therefore no fragments in this function require investigation for Rule 14.3 (controlling expressions shall not be invariant). If there is concern that any of these runtime values are in practice constant in a particular build/configuration, that project-specific evidence should be provided for further review.
